awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Modeling Mental Representation in Judgment
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent advances in machine learning, combined with the increased availability of large natural language online datasets, have opened up new opportunities for understanding human behavior. With these new methods, it is now possible to observe what people read and talk about, and thus think and feel about, a wide range of common objects and events. The goal of this project is to study how these novel methods and datasets can be combined with existing psychological theory to predict and understand human judgment, with the primary application to the domain of risk perception. The computational techniques proposed as part of this project allow for the automatic, large-scale analysis of the perception of naturalistic risks, and thus can be used to identify problems and develop interventions involving risk communication and risk management. More generally, by applying cutting edge methods in data science to the study of human behavior, this project develops novel technologies for predicting and understanding attitudes, beliefs, and preferences. By doing so, it facilitates a wide array of policy and commercial applications not feasible using existing empirical methodologies in the behavioral sciences.

How can we uncover and quantify rich mental representations for all of the objects and concepts that are the target of everyday judgment? How can we use these rich representations to predict judgments and judgment errors, to study domain and individual-level differences in judgment, and to characterize the complex web of associations that underlie judgment? Finally, how can we study differences in mental representations and judgments across cultures and time periods? This project will use "semantic vectors" -- high dimensional representations for words obtained from large-scale language data -- to address these questions. Semantic vectors provide a good proxy for the structure of knowledge and association in people's minds and can be combined with various machine learning algorithms to predict judgments for naturalistic objects and concepts, such as sources of risk. These vectors can also identify the key associates of judgments, facilitating directed hypothesis tests for a diverse array of psychological dimensions, including emotions, moral concepts, and personality. Finally, when trained on different types of language datasets, semantic vectors can shed light on the complex interaction between judgment and culture, history, and society. Note that semantic vectors can be used in this manner for nearly any judgment domain that involves common objects, individuals, and events. Thus one key goal of this project is to evaluate the applicability of semantic vectors for predicting and understanding the many different types of judgments that that people make on a day-to-day basis (including not only risk judgment, but also, for example, health judgment and consumer judgment).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant was awarded in 2019, with the goal of developing and disseminating computational techniques that combine advances in machine learning with large natural language datasets to study human judgment and decision making, primarily in the domain of risk perception. The grant aimed to 1. create tools that quantify people’s mental representations for (what they know about and associate with) various everyday objects and concepts, 2. use these representations to predict people’s judgments with high accuracy and generality, and 3. uncover the underlying associations and thought processes influencing people’s judgments. The project also sought to extend these methods to study errors in judgment, as well as differences in judgments across various individuals, geographic regions, cultures, and time.

During the five-year period of the grant, significant advances were made in natural language processing and machine learning, ranging from improved methods for representing words and sentences to generative AI capable of creating language. We actively kept up with these advances. For example, while we initially used word embeddings --which are dense vectors that capture semantic relationships between words-- for modeling representations of individual objects like risk sources, we eventually progressed to using sentence embeddings –dense vectors for capturing the meanings of sentences-- for modeling thoughts and reasons that influence people’s risky decisions, and finally to generative AI for modeling complex relational or structured knowledge for the objects.

Through our research we generated several publications that demonstrate the applicability of these technologies to decision research and how they can be combined with existing theories in the field to improve the prediction and understanding of behavior. Additionally, thanks to NSF funding, we were able to lead workshops at universities and conferences to train new generations of scholars in these methods. Through these activities, we have ensured that the study of decision making and psychology remains connected to methodological advances in machine learning and artificial intelligence, and have layed the groundwork for a long-term research program applying these advances to the study of human behavior.

We were fortunate to receive the NSF career award at such an opportune time, which allowed us to closely follow the most important technological advances of our era. We are proud that our efforts have not only advanced scholarship in our field, but also improved the well-being of individuals by enabling the quantitative study of naturalistic judgment, and facilitating the development of behavioral interventions in risk, health, and financial decision making. Finally, through our research, workshops and mentorship efforts, we have trained many young researchers in these cutting-edge technologies, leading to the dissemination of these important tools and methods across academia and industry, and ultimately enhancing the economic competitiveness of the United States.
